question: The number of dental caries cases reported during last 10 years are given below 250, 320, 190, 300, 5000, 100, 260, 350, 320 and 160. The epidemiologist wants to find out average number of caries cases reported in that town for last 10 yrs. The most appropriate average per this data will be
prompt:
The number of dental caries cases reported during last 10 years are given below 250, 320, 190, 300, 5000, 100, 260, 350, 320 and 160. The epidemiologist wants to find out average number of caries cases reported in that town for last 10 yrs. The most appropriate average per this data will beA)Arithmetic mean
B)Mode
C)Median
D)Geometric mean
output0: The arithmetic mean is the most appropriate average to use when dealing with a set of continuous data, such as the number of dental caries cases reported over the last 10 years. It is calculated by adding up all the values and dividing by the number of values. In this case, the average number of caries cases reported in the last 10 years is:
output1: The mode is the most appropriate average for this data because it represents the most frequently occurring value. In this case, the mode is the value that appears most frequently in the data set, which is 300.
output2: The median is the most appropriate average for this data set because it is not affected by extreme values, such as the large number of caries cases reported in one year (5000). The median is the middle value in the data set when the data is arranged in order, so it is a good measure of the typical or average number of caries cases reported in the town over the last 10 years.
output3: The geometric mean is the most appropriate average for this data because it takes into account the fact that the data are a set of positive numbers that increase over time. The arithmetic mean, on the other hand, would be influenced by the extreme values in the data set (5000 and 100), and the mode and median would not accurately represent the trend in the data.

question: According to the definition of the American Spinal Injury Association (ASIA), the key muscle (key muscle) Check the third lumbar spinal cord (L3) at the disposal of the motor function is:
prompt:
According to the definition of the American Spinal Injury Association (ASIA), the key muscle (key muscle) Check the third lumbar spinal cord (L3) at the disposal of the motor function is:A)髂腰 skin (iliopsoas)
B)Quads (quadriceps)
C)Tibia before skin (tibialis anterior)
D)Gastrocnemius muscle (gastrocnemius)
output0: The key muscle for the third lumbar spinal cord (L3) is the iliopsoas muscle. This muscle is responsible for flexion and extension of the hip joint, as well as for maintaining posture and balance.
output1: The key muscle for the third lumbar spinal cord (L3) at the disposal of the motor function, according to the definition of the American Spinal Injury Association (ASIA), is the quads (quadriceps). This muscle is responsible for extending the knee and hip joints, which is an important function for standing, walking, and balance.
output2: The tibialis anterior muscle is a key muscle that is responsible for knee flexion and extension. It is located in the lower leg and is connected to the third lumbar spinal cord (L3) at the disposal of the motor function, as defined by the American Spinal Injury Association (ASIA).
output3: The gastrocnemius muscle is the main muscle responsible for plantarflexion (pointing the foot downward) of the foot. It is located in the back of the lower leg and is innervated by the L3 spinal cord segment.

question: Danazol acts through :?
prompt:
Danazol acts through :?A)Increases release of Gn
B)Increases insulin release
C)Inhibition of release of Gn
D)Inhibition of insulin release
output0: Danazol acts by increasing the release of gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH), which stimulates the production of sex hormones.
output1: Danazol, a drug used to treat endometriosis, acts by increasing insulin release. This helps to reduce the growth of endometrial tissue and alleviate symptoms associated with the condition.
output2: Danazol is a synthetic androgen that acts by inhibiting the release of gonadotropin (Gn) from the pituitary gland. This inhibition leads to a decrease in the production of sex hormones, such as estrogen and testosterone, and is used to treat endometriosis and other hormone-related disorders.
output3: Danazol acts by inhibiting the release of insulin, which is a hormone that helps regulate blood sugar levels. By inhibiting the release of insulin, danazol can help to increase blood sugar levels.

question: Most common age for intussusception is
prompt:
Most common age for intussusception isA)0-6 Months
B)6 Months -3yrs
C)3-5 Yrs
D)> 5 yrs
output0: Intussusception is most common in children under the age of 6 months. In fact, the majority of cases occur in children between 0 and 3 months old.
output1: Intussusception is most common in children between 6 months and 3 years of age. This is because the intestine is still developing and is more prone to telescoping during this time.
output2: Intussusception is most common in children between the ages of 3 and 5 years old. This is because the intestines are still developing and are more prone to telescoping during this age range.
output3: Intussusception is a type of bowel obstruction that is most common in children under the age of 5, but it can occur at any age. The majority of cases occur between 6 months and 3 years of age.

question: As a public health practitioner, you are charged with choosing which blood test to use for the screening of a new infectious disease. You want to ensure that as many cases of this disease as possible are picked up by this initial screening test. Which of the following is the highest priority characteristic of this new test?
prompt:
As a public health practitioner, you are charged with choosing which blood test to use for the screening of a new infectious disease. You want to ensure that as many cases of this disease as possible are picked up by this initial screening test. Which of the following is the highest priority characteristic of this new test?A)Highly sensitive test
B)Low false positive rate
C)High true positive rate
D)Low negative predictive value
output0: The highest priority characteristic of a screening test for a new infectious disease is that it be highly sensitive, meaning that it can detect as many cases of the disease as possible. This is because the goal of screening is to identify as many cases as possible, even if it means that some false positives may occur.
output1: The highest priority characteristic of a screening test for a new infectious disease is a low false positive rate. This is because a low false positive rate reduces the number of individuals who are incorrectly identified as having the disease, which can lead to unnecessary testing, treatment, and potential harm to the individual.
output2: The highest priority characteristic of a blood test for screening a new infectious disease is a high true positive rate. This means that the test should be highly accurate at identifying individuals who have the disease, rather than incorrectly identifying healthy individuals as having the disease (false negatives). A high true positive rate is essential to ensure that as many cases of the disease as possible are picked up by the initial screening test.
output3: The highest priority characteristic of a screening test for a new infectious disease is a low negative predictive value. This means that the test should be able to correctly identify patients who do not have the disease, as these patients will not be subjected to further testing or treatment. A highly sensitive test with a high true positive rate and a low false positive rate would be the next priorities.

question: Inhibin levels are checked on which day of menstrual cycle ?
prompt:
Inhibin levels are checked on which day of menstrual cycle ?A)Day 3
B)Day 4
C)Day 5
D)Day 6
output0: The best time to check inhibin levels is on Day 3 of the menstrual cycle. Inhibin levels are highest on this day, making it the most accurate time to assess ovulation.
output1: Inhibin levels are typically checked on Day 4 of the menstrual cycle. This is because inhibin is produced by the placenta during the early stages of pregnancy, and its levels are highest on Day 4.
output2: Inhibin levels are typically checked on Day 5 of the menstrual cycle, as this is when the levels of this hormone are highest. This allows for more accurate measurements and better detection of any potential issues with ovulation.
output3: Inhibin levels are typically checked on Day 6 of the menstrual cycle because this is when the levels of the hormone are highest. Inhibin is a hormone produced by the placenta during pregnancy, and its levels can be used to confirm or rule out pregnancy.

question: D.O.C for isospora
prompt:
D.O.C for isosporaA)Penicillin G
B)Benzathine penicillin
C)Co-trimoxazole
D)Albendazole
output0: Penicillin G is the most effective treatment for Isospora infections, which are common in children. It works by killing the parasites in the intestine, which helps to reduce symptoms and prevent complications.
output1: Benzathine penicillin is the antibiotic of choice for the treatment of isosporiasis, a parasitic infection caused by the protozoan Isospora belli.
output2: Co-trimoxazole is the most appropriate antibiotic for the treatment of isosporiasis, as it is effective against both Isospora belli and I. hominis.
output3: Albendazole is an antiparasitic drug that is used to treat Isospora infections. It is the most effective treatment for this condition and is recommended by the World Health Organization (WHO) as the first-line treatment for Isospora infections in children.

question:
A 55-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with altered mental status. The patient is in acute distress and cannot provide history due to disorientation. Temperature is 38.7°C (101.6°F), blood pressure is 80/50 mm Hg, pulse is 103/min, respiratory rate is 22/min, and BMI is 20 kg/m2. On examination, his sclera and skin are icteric. On abdominal examination, the patient moans with deep palpation to his right upper quadrant.
Laboratory test
Complete blood count
Hemoglobin 14.5 g/dL
MCV 88 fl
Leukocytes 16,500/mm3
Platelets 170,000/mm3
Basic metabolic panel
Serum Na+ 147 mEq/L
Serum K+ 3.8 mEq/L
Serum Cl- 106 mEq/L
Serum HCO3- 25 mEq/L
BUN 30 mg/dL
Serum creatinine 1.2 mg/dL
Liver function test
Total bilirubin 2.8 mg/dL
AST 50 U/L
ALT 65 U/L
ALP 180 U/L
The patient is treated urgently with intravenous fluid, dopamine, and broad spectrum antibiotics. The patient’s blood pressure improves to 101/70 mm Hg. On ultrasound of the abdomen, the common bile duct is dilated. What is the best next step in the management of this patient?
prompt:
A 55-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with altered mental status. The patient is in acute distress and cannot provide history due to disorientation. Temperature is 38.7°C (101.6°F), blood pressure is 80/50 mm Hg, pulse is 103/min, respiratory rate is 22/min, and BMI is 20 kg/m2. On examination, his sclera and skin are icteric. On abdominal examination, the patient moans with deep palpation to his right upper quadrant.
Laboratory test
Complete blood count
Hemoglobin 14.5 g/dL
MCV 88 fl
Leukocytes 16,500/mm3
Platelets 170,000/mm3
Basic metabolic panel
Serum Na+ 147 mEq/L
Serum K+ 3.8 mEq/L
Serum Cl- 106 mEq/L
Serum HCO3- 25 mEq/L
BUN 30 mg/dL
Serum creatinine 1.2 mg/dL
Liver function test
Total bilirubin 2.8 mg/dL
AST 50 U/L
ALT 65 U/L
ALP 180 U/L
The patient is treated urgently with intravenous fluid, dopamine, and broad spectrum antibiotics. The patient’s blood pressure improves to 101/70 mm Hg. On ultrasound of the abdomen, the common bile duct is dilated. What is the best next step in the management of this patient?A)ERCP
B)MRCP
C)Percutaneous transhepatic cholangiogram
D)CT abdomen
output0: The patient's presentation of altered mental status, icteric sclera and skin, and abdominal pain with deep palpation to the right upper quadrant, along with the laboratory results of elevated bilirubin, AST, and ALT, indicate acute liver injury. The ultrasound finding of a dilated common bile duct is consistent with a diagnosis of acute cholangitis. The best next step in the management of this patient is ERCP, which is a minimally invasive procedure that can be used to diagnose and treat biliary disorders.
output1: The best next step in the management of this patient is a magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP) to further evaluate the dilated common bile duct. MRCP is a non-invasive imaging modality that can provide detailed information about the biliary tree and pancreas, which can help guide further management.
output2: The patient’s symptoms and laboratory results suggest acute cholangitis, and the ultrasound findings of a dilated common bile duct support this diagnosis. The best next step in the management of this patient would be a percutaneous transhepatic cholangiogram (PTC) to confirm the diagnosis and assess the severity of the disease.
output3: The patient’s presentation of altered mental status, icterus, and abdominal pain suggests a possible diagnosis of acute cholangitis. The ultrasound finding of a dilated common bile duct supports this diagnosis. The best next step in the management of this patient would be to perform a CT abdomen to further evaluate the extent of the disease and to look for any other possible causes of the patient’s symptoms.

question: How is an epileptic state (or status epilepticus) defined in a pediatric patient ?:
correct_answer: Excessive neuronal discharge in the cerebral cortex with duration equal to or greater than 30 minutes.
options: A)Excessive neuronal discharge in the cerebral cortex with duration equal to or greater than 5 minutes.
B)Excessive neuronal discharge in the cerebral cortex with duration equal to or greater than 15 minutes.
C)Excessive neuronal discharge in the cerebral cortex with duration equal to or greater than 30 minutes.
D)Excessive neuronal discharge in the cerebral cortex with duration equal to or greater than 60 minutes.
prompt:
How is an epileptic state (or status epilepticus) defined in a pediatric patient ?:A)Excessive neuronal discharge in the cerebral cortex with duration equal to or greater than 5 minutes.
B)Excessive neuronal discharge in the cerebral cortex with duration equal to or greater than 15 minutes.
C)Excessive neuronal discharge in the cerebral cortex with duration equal to or greater than 30 minutes.
D)Excessive neuronal discharge in the cerebral cortex with duration equal to or greater than 60 minutes.
output0: In pediatric patients, an epileptic state (or status epilepticus) is defined as excessive neuronal discharge in the cerebral cortex that lasts for 5 minutes or more. This is the most common definition used in clinical practice.
output1: In pediatric patients, an epileptic state or status epilepticus is defined as excessive neuronal discharge in the cerebral cortex that lasts for more than 15 minutes. This definition is used to distinguish between acute seizures and status epilepticus, which is a more prolonged and severe seizure disorder.
output2: In pediatric patients, an epileptic state (or status epilepticus) is defined as excessive neuronal discharge in the cerebral cortex that lasts for more than 30 minutes. This is the longest duration recommended by the International League Against Epilepsy (ILAE) for diagnosing a status epilepticus in children.
output3: In pediatric patients, an epileptic state (or status epilepticus) is defined as excessive neuronal discharge in the cerebral cortex with a duration equal to or greater than 60 minutes. This is because children's brains are still developing and are more susceptible to seizures and other neurological disorders.

question: Dr Bernhard Giesenhagen gave which of the following
prompt:
Dr Bernhard Giesenhagen gave which of the followingA)Bone ring technique
B)Bone flap technique
C)Overlap technique
D)Bone pouch technique
output0: Dr. Bernhard Giesenhagen is known for developing the Bone Ring Technique, which is used to help children with ADHD, Autism, and other neurological disorders. This technique involves using a ring to help children focus and regulate their emotions.
output1: Dr. Bernhard Giesenhagen is known for his work on the bone flap technique, which is a variation of the Turtle Technique. The bone flap technique involves the use of a bone flap to help the child regulate their breathing and calm their nervous system.
output2: Dr. Bernhard Giesenhagen is known for developing the Overlap Technique, which is a specific application of the Turtle Technique. This technique involves applying gentle pressure to the bones of the hand to encourage the development of better self-control and emotional regulation skills.
output3: Dr. Bernhard Giesenhagen is a well-known German pediatric dentist who developed the Turtle Technique. He used the Bone Pouch Technique to treat children with dental anxiety. This technique involves placing a bone pouch over the child's teeth to help them feel safe and secure.
